docs.lead_paragraph: Abusive bosses and unfair workplaces can be bad for the health of both employees and companies, two new studies suggest. In a study published yesterday in The Journal of Applied Psychology, researchers from the University of North Carolina at Charlotte surveyed 373 Air National Guard members and their supervisors.

headline.main: Abuse Takes Toll on Bottom Line

docs.abstract: Researchers from University of North Carolina, in study published in Journal of Applied Psychology, suggests that Air National Guard members whose supervisers are abusive are far more likely to perform only minimum required of them; study of hospital workers published in Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine finds that number of sick days taken is strongly influenced by perception of fairness in workplace, with women appearing to be affected more than men; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Abusive bosses and unfair workplaces can be bad for the health of both employees and companies, two new studies suggest.     In a study published yesterday in The Journal of Applied Psychology, researchers from the University of North Carolina at...

docs.lead_paragraph: Jillian Polis, a second-year medical student at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University, admits that she had little if any experience with substance abuse. Raised in a suburb of Denver, she learned about drugs from popular culture. ''I thought the only people who got addicted were those who were wealthy with nothing to do or the urban poor,'' said Ms. Polis, 23. ''I got those images from movies like 'Traffic' since there was little or no addiction that I knew of growing up.' ''

headline.main: Recovering Addicts Help Educate Future Doctors

docs.abstract: Article on monthly sessions in which medical students at Cornell University's Weill Medical College meet with residents of Phoenix House, drug treatment center in Queens, NY, in order to better understand drug addiction and develop empathy for addicted patients; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Back Sense,'' by Dr. Ronald D. Siegel, Michael H. Urdang and Dr. Douglas R. Johnson. Broadway Books, $12.95. Back pain is a complaint that generates surprising statistics for the American health care system: it disables more than five million people every year, costs society $20 billion to $25 billion a year for treatment and lost productivity and is the leading cause of disability for people under 45.
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book Back Sense by Dr Ronald D Siegel, Michael H Urdang and Dr Douglas R Johnson; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1989, when a government report suggested that gay teenagers were at high risk for suicide attempts, lesbian and gay rights advocates welcomed the finding as long overdue. They said the report, one of the first to address the health of gay youth, offered compelling evidence of what they had maintained for years -- that prejudice had damaged gay adolescents' psychological well-being.

headline.main: A New Dimension in Snapshot of Gay Teenagers

docs.abstract: Article on recent research suggesting that earlier studies may be flawed and significantly overstate degree of self-destructive behavior of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender teenagers; Cornell University professor of developmental and clinical psychology Dr Ritch Savin-Williams says research is pathologizing gay youth by focusing attention on those who are at risk rather than on large majority who appear to be doing well; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In 1989, when a government report suggested that gay teenagers were at high risk for suicide attempts, lesbian and gay rights advocates welcomed the finding as long overdue.    They said the report, one of the first to address the health of gay...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 1950's, doctors were bitterly divided about an issue that seems eerily modern. What, they asked, is the point of finding breast cancer early? On one side were the surgeons who passionately argued that small tumors were the ones that could be cured. As cancers grow, surgeons said, they develop an ability to spread and kill. So the best way to stop cancer is to find it as soon as possible, cut it out and blast the area with X-rays, as chemotherapy was not yet being used for breast cancer.

headline.main: Early Detection of Cancer: Nothing Is Black and White

docs.abstract: Analysis of debate in 1950's between surgeons who argued that small breast tumors needed to detected and excised early to stop cancer from spreading and doctors who said early detection was being oversold and that some tumors, regardless of size, would spread beyond breast and kill and others would remain harmless; now, pre-determinist argument is re-emerging but few say it is entirely right or wrong; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: In the 1950's, doctors were bitterly divided about an issue that seems eerily modern. What, they asked, is the point of finding breast cancer early?     On one side were the surgeons who passionately argued that small tumors were the ones that could...

docs.lead_paragraph: Teenagers -- one minute they're on top of the world, the next they're down in the dumps. One minute you're the best dad or mom there ever was. The next you're the world's worst, and they're threatening to leave home. As their lives, bodies and hormones change, teenagers can find themselves on an emotional seesaw with no way off. Not all teenagers, of course. Some are rather even-tempered, always up or always down or somewhere in between.

headline.main: Adolescent Angst or a Deeper Disorder? Tips for Spotting Serious Symptoms

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on teenage depression; focuses on its causes and long-lasting consequences, symptoms and treatment; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who had heart bypass surgery fared better if their husbands were shown a video before the operation that presented an optimistic view of the recovery, a study has found. Many studies have found that wives do a better job of caring for husbands than husbands do for wives. And in the new study, published this month in the journal Health Psychology, the 70 women who were patients had a higher rate of complications and return visits to the hospital in the six months after surgery than the 226 men.
docs.abstract: Researchers at University of California at San Diego, in study published in journal Health Psychology, find that group of women who underwent heart bypass surgery whose husbands were shown video before operation that presented highly optimistic view of recovery returned to hospital 25 percent less often and had fewer complications and signs of mental distress than control group; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Women who had heart bypass surgery fared better if their husbands were shown a video before the operation that presented an optimistic view of the recovery, a study has found.    Many studies have found that wives do a better job of caring for...

docs.lead_paragraph: A rhesus monkey, only 4 months old, has been pried from the shoulders of its sedated mother and let into a small steel cage. Within minutes the fright in its little brown eyes softens into curiosity, and stepping tentatively, the monkey makes its way across the cage. But when a man with a white hood over his head strides in and stops two feet away, the baby freezes. It pulls its body close to the bars and quietly looks the other way, appearing to ignore the man until, two minutes later, he leaves.

headline.main: Lab Monkeys May Reveal Secrets of Childhood Depression

docs.abstract: Article on research on baby rhesus monkeys being conducted by Dr Judy Cameron, neurobiologist and director of University of Pittsburgh's primate laboratory; Cameron, seeking clues to adolescent depression, has found that 8 to 10 percent of monkeys tested show high degree of anxiety and that they produce less growth hormone; studies over last 25 years have found that about 8 percent of teens between 14 and 18 years old suffer from clinical depression; photos; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: A rhesus monkey, only 4 months old, has been pried from the shoulders of its sedated mother and let into a small steel cage. Within minutes the fright in its little brown eyes softens into curiosity, and stepping tentatively, the monkey makes its way...

docs.lead_paragraph: The results of a small experiment published today suggest that tinnitus -- ringing in the ears -- may in effect be ''jammed'' by using magnets to stimulate an area in the brain that processes sound. The lead researcher, Dr. Christian Gerloff of the University of Tuebingen in Germany, said the experiment was meant to test a new concept that compared tinnitus to the kind of ''phantom pain'' felt by people who had lost a limb. If the sounds were being produced by abnormal brain activity, the researchers speculated, perhaps they could be reduced if that abnormal activity was temporarily overriden by an external stimulus.

headline.main: A Magnet That Quiets a Roar

docs.abstract: Preliminary research led by Dr Christian Gerloff of University of Tuebingen in Germany suggests that tinnitus--ringing in ears--may be effectively 'jammed' by using magnets to stimulate brain's left temporoparietal cortex, which processes sound (M)
docs.snippet: The results of a small experiment published today suggest that tinnitus -- ringing in the ears -- may in effect be ''jammed'' by using magnets to stimulate an area in the brain that processes sound.    The lead researcher, Dr. Christian Gerloff of...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the last year, the world of infectious diseases has begun to lose its bearings. The simple John Wayne-like world where the good guys (vaccines, antibiotics and hand washing) chase away the bad guys (bacteria, viruses and all the rest) is fading fast into the sunset. Rather, some investigators are arguing that, contrary to your mother's (and everyone else's) advice, many of us are not receiving enough infections. Writing recently in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Scott Weiss of the Channing Laboratory at Harvard, referred to the new focus as the ''eat dirt'' approach to health.

headline.main: Can Dirt Really Be Good for People? Maybe. But a Little Goes a Long Way.

docs.abstract: Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center hospital infection control director Dr Kent Sepkowitz essay explores notion, addressed by Scott Weiss of Harvard University's Channing Laboratory in recent New England Journal of Medicine, that routine constant low-grade infections keep immune systems fit and ready (M)
docs.snippet: In the last year, the world of infectious diseases has begun to lose its bearings. The simple John Wayne-like world where the good guys (vaccines, antibiotics and hand washing) chase away the bad guys (bacteria, viruses and all the rest) is fading...
